pros:
Initial training is classroom based and helpful/relevant. This lasts about a month and is M-F. On the job training follows for about another month where you gain exposure to all the shifts you may work. 

Schedule is immensely flexible once you are released from training. You can trade with coworkers and double shifts to get more time off. Shifts are 6am-2pm, 2pm-10pm and 10pm-6am. Schedule is seniority based, meaning the longer you are here, the more likely you are to get your desired shifts. 

Time off good. Basically 3 weeks of paid time off with an option to purchase another week. Time off is also seniority based. Expect to work holidays for a while after getting hired. 

Coworkers and management are mostly helpful when you have questions or concerns. 

This is a stepping stone to other departments at United. Keep that in mind when you read the cons. 

Not a con but something you need to be aware of. You are locked in to this department for one year. If you choose to move up to Coordinator, that year resets. If you don’t want this ensure you get it in writing from HR. But good luck with that.
cons:
A lot of duties and responsibilities are left out of the job description. For instance, once released from training, you are expected to train other new schedulers. Not sure why the company thinks this is a good idea. The amount of workload is generally high enough to keep a new scheduler busy let alone having to also worry about training somebody. Even if you are uncomfortable with training, they appear to not care. Very bad look when you are doing your first on the job training shift and your trainee says “I don’t like training.” Mind you, there are plenty of schedulers who like to train. Perhaps the company can work with those schedulers instead of forcing new schedulers to train. 

Secondly, there are a copious amount of operational issues that are left alone simply because “that is how it is done”. I won’t get into details but know that these issues make this job more difficult. 

Third, as an employee, it is not my job to ensure the company pays me properly for the shifts I work. Yes, you read that right. I have to take time out of my day to ensure I get paid correctly. If you work a PM or MID shift, or any overtime, you have to ensure it is loaded into one of the many cumbersome systems that some pencil pusher though was a one size fits all solution. Mind you, all of our shifts are loaded into a scheduling platform (RosterApps). One would think that the information in RosterApps could just feed to payroll. But apparently that makes too much sense. They choose to pull managers out of the operation to audit this system. Yep. Good business decision. Oh, and even if it is completely right, they will still manage to over or underpay you. 

Fourth, be prepared for about four different answers when you ask a question. I had an operational issue recently that several people insisted was ok, yet no one could provide me an answer as to why it was ok. Even our scheduling software seemed to agree with my analysis of the issue. 

Fifth, upper management does not care about retention or employee morale. During the pandemic United moved most of its operations personnel to a work from home model. Over two and a half years, and seemingly no disruption (in fact the company CEO even touted the employees for record setting performance) the company is terminating its work from home option for operational staff. After multiple meetings where we expressed our disappointment with the decision we were told “well its always been the plan to return, so thats what we are doing”. What a sorry excuse. Especially given how flexible you have to be for the company. 

The technology is subpar to say the least. Its typical antiquated airline computer software. Lots of manual typing of commands and very quirky. Its amazing the airline  runs on it. To be fair, they are updating it to a more modern system, but that will be a 5+ year endeavor.
